title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the trend in total seafood production in India between 1960 and 2016, such as any the following:

· Production increases steadily/exponentially from 1960 until 2016.

· Production increases by more than 5 times during the time period.

The response describes the trend in total seafood production in India between 1960 and 2016, such as one the following:

· Production increases steadily/exponentially from 1960 until 2016.

· Production increases by more than 5 times during the time period.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the years in which wild-caught seafood production exceeded seafood production by aquaculture in India as 1960 to 2013 or 2014.
The response identifies the years in which wild-caught seafood production exceeded seafood production by aquaculture in India as 1960 to 2013 or 2014.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain one possible reason why aquaculture production in India changed between 1990 and 2016, such as any of the following:

· Rapid economic and population growth in India lead to an increased demand for fish/food.

· Increased wealth and demand for high-quality protein sources.

· Aquaculture technology has improved/is more efficient than traditional seafood harvesting.

· Loss in availability of wild-caught fish in the region.

The response explains one possible reason why aquaculture production in India changed between 1990 and 2016, such as one of the following:

· Rapid economic and population growth in India lead to an increased demand for fish/food.

· Increased wealth and demand for high-quality protein sources.

· Aquaculture technology has improved/is more efficient than traditional seafood harvesting.

· Loss in availability of wild-caught fish in the region.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how regulations can be used to reduce the impact of the environmental problems that result from the public ownership of fisheries, such as any of the following:

· By establishing quotas or size restrictions on catching fish, populations can be maintained at sufficient size and with sufficient reproductive potential to maintain a heathy population.

· Because fish populations are a shared resource, regulations can reduce harvest for self-interest and keep the resource from being depleted.

The response explains how regulations can be used to reduce the impact of the environmental problems that result from the public ownership of fisheries, such as one of the following:

· By establishing quotas or size restrictions on catching fish, populations can be maintained at sufficient size and with sufficient reproductive potential to maintain a heathy population.

· Because fish populations are a shared resource, regulations can reduce harvest for self-interest and keep the resource from being depleted.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim using evidence that supports or refutes the assertion that purchasing farmed tilapia is a better choice for the environment than purchasing farmed salmon, such as the following:

· Tilapia are primary consumers and eat lower on the food chain. This means they require less energy/biomass to produce, which is better for the environment.

The response makes a claim using evidence that supports or refutes the assertion that purchasing farmed tilapia is a better choice for the environment than purchasing farmed salmon, such as the following:

· Tilapia are primary consumers and eat lower on the food chain. This means they require less energy/biomass to produce, which is better for the environment.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim by citing an environmental problem associated with one of the options that supports or refutes the assertion that purchasing farmed scallops is a better choice for the environment than purchasing wild-caught scallops, such as any of the following:

Farmed Scallops

· Can increase nutrient concentration in water causing algal blooms

· Grown in high population densities and are vulnerable to hosting and spreading diseases and parasites

Wild-caught Scallops

· Harvested by bottom trawling, which kills non-target species that may be subject to overfishing

· Trawlers consume much fossil fuel to reach fishing grounds and operate equipment resulting in increased levels of sulfur dioxide, particulates, and carbon dioxide emissions

· Endanger wild scallop populations that are subject to overharvest

· Reduce the availability of scallops in the food chain/web

The response makes a claim by citing an environmental problem associated with one of the options that supports or refutes the assertion that purchasing farmed scallops is a better choice for the environment than purchasing wild-caught scallops, such as one of the following:

Farmed Scallops

· Can increase nutrient concentration in water causing algal blooms

· Grown in high population densities and are vulnerable to hosting and spreading diseases and parasites

Wild-caught Scallops

· Harvested by bottom trawling, which kills non-target species that may be subject to overfishing

· Trawlers consume much fossil fuel to reach fishing grounds and operate equipment resulting in increased levels of sulfur dioxide, particulates, and carbon dioxide emissions

· Endanger wild scallop populations that are subject to overharvest

· Reduce the availability of scallops in the food chain/web

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not propose a solution to the environmental problem cited in part (f), such as any of the following:

Can increase nutrient concentration in water causing algal blooms (problem in part (f)).

· Move scallop farms further out to sea to better dilute pollutants

Grown in high population densities and are vulnerable to hosting and spreading diseases and parasites (problem in part (f)).

· Administer medication to protect them from disease

Harvested by bottom trawling, which kills non-target species that may be subject to overfishing (problem in part (f)).

· Harvest scallops by hand

Trawlers consume much fossil fuel to reach fishing grounds and operate equipment resulting in increased levels of sulfur dioxide, particulates, and carbon dioxide emissions (problem in part (f)).

· Switch to lower emission, cleaner burning fuel like liquified natural gas.

Endanger wild scallop populations that are subject to overharvest or reduce the availability of scallops in the food chain/web (problem in part (f)).

· Enforce strict quotas or limits on the number of scallops that can be harvested.

The response proposes a solution to the environmental problem cited in part (f), such as one of the following:

Can increase nutrient concentration in water causing algal blooms (problem in part (f)).

· Move scallop farms further out to sea to better dilute pollutants

Grown in high population densities and are vulnerable to hosting and spreading diseases and parasites (problem in part (f)).

· Administer medication to protect them from disease

Harvested by bottom trawling, which kills non-target species that may be subject to overfishing (problem in part (f)).

· Harvest scallops by hand

Trawlers consume much fossil fuel to reach fishing grounds and operate equipment resulting in increased levels of sulfur dioxide, particulates, and carbon dioxide emissions (problem in part (f)).

· Switch to lower emission, cleaner burning fuel like liquified natural gas.

Endanger wild scallop populations that are subject to overharvest or reduce the availability of scallops in the food chain/web (problem in part (f)).

· Enforce strict quotas or limits on the number of scallops that can be harvested.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one disadvantage or unintended consequence that could result from the solution proposed in part (g), such as any of the following:

Move scallop farms further out to sea to better dilute pollutants (solution in part (g))

· More fuel will be required to service the enclosures.

· Could be more susceptible to damage from storms

Administer medication to protect them from disease (solution in part (g))

· Increases the concentration of pharmaceuticals in the environment

· Increases the possibility of organisms evolving resistance

Harvest scallops by hand (solution in part (g))

· Dangerous for divers

· Limits the production/harvest of scallops

· Economic costs associated with harvesting by hand

Switch to lower emission, cleaner burning fuel like liquified natural gas (solution in part (g))

· Expense of switching to new technology

· Could decrease the range of the boat

· It could be difficult to get fuel

Enforce strict quotas or limits on the number of scallops that can be harvested (solution in part (g))

· Additional cost of enforcing regulations/requires additional regulators and monitoring

· Economic impacts on those that harvest scallops
